H ow do we tell the difference between what is alive and what is not alive? If we see a dog running, or a cow chewing cud, or a man shouting loudly on the street, we know that these are living beings. What if the dog or the cow or the man were asleep? We would still think that they were alive, but how did we know that? We see them breathing, and we know that they are alive. What about plants? How do we know that they are alive? We see them green, some of us will say. But what about plants that have leaves of colours other than green? They grow over time, so we know that they are alive, some will say. In other words, we tend to think of some sort of movement, either growth-related or not, as common evidence for being alive. But a plant that is not visibly growing is still alive, and some animals can breathe without visible movement. So using visible movement as the defining characteristic of life is not enough.

Movements over very small scales will be invisible to the naked eye – movements of molecules, for example. Is this invisible molecular movement necessary for life? If we ask this question to professional biologists, they will say yes. In fact, viruses do not show any molecular movement in them (until they infect some cell), and that is partly why there is a controversy about whether they are truly alive or not.

Why are molecular movements needed for life? We have seen in earlier classes that living organisms are well-organised structures; they can have tissues, tissues have cells, cells have smaller components in them, and so on. Because of the effects of the environment, this organised, ordered nature of living structures is very likely to keep breaking down over time. If order breaks down, the organism will no longer be alive. So living creatures must keep repairing and maintaining their structures. Since all these structures are made up of molecules, they must move molecules around all the time.

What are the maintenance processes in living organisms? Let us explore.

## 5.1 WHAT ARE LIFE PROCESSES?

The maintenance functions of living organisms must go on even when they are not doing anything particular. Even when we are just sitting in class, even if we are just asleep, this maintenance job has to go on. The processes which together perform this maintenance job are life processes.

Since these maintenance processes are needed to prevent damage and break-down, energy is needed for them. This energy comes from outside the body of the individual organism. So there must be a process to transfer a source of energy from outside the body of the organism, which we call food, to the inside, a process we commonly call nutrition. If the body size of the organisms is to grow, additional raw material will also be needed from outside. Since life on earth depends on carbonbased molecules, most of these food sources are also carbon-based. Depending on the complexity of these carbon sources, different organisms can then use different kinds of nutritional processes.

The outside sources of energy could be quite varied, since the environment is not under the control of the individual organism. These sources of energy, therefore, need to be broken down or built up in the body, and must be finally converted to a uniform source of energy that can be used for the various molecular movements needed for maintaining living structures, as well as to the kind of molecules the body needs to grow. For this, a series of chemical reactions in the body are necessary. Oxidising-reducing reactions are some of the most common chemical means to break-down molecules. For this, many organisms use oxygen sourced from outside the body. The process of acquiring oxygen from outside the body, and to use it in the process of break-down of food sources for cellular needs, is what we call respiration.

In the case of a single-celled organism, no specific organs for taking in food, exchange of gases or removal of wastes may be needed because the entire surface of the organism is in contact with the environment. But what happens when the body size of the organism increases and the body design becomes more complex? In multi-cellular organisms, all the cells may not be in direct contact with the surrounding environment. Thus, simple diffusion will not meet the requirements of all the cells.

We have seen previously how, in multi-cellular organisms, various body parts have specialised in the functions they perform. We are familiar with the idea of these specialised tissues, and with their organisation in the body of the organism. It is therefore not surprising that the uptake of food and of oxygen will also be the function of specialised tissues. However, this poses a problem, since the food and oxygen are now taken up at one place in the body of the organisms, while all parts of the body need them. This situation creates a need for a transportation system for carrying food and oxygen from one place to another in the body.

When chemical reactions use the carbon source and the oxygen for energy generation, they create by-products that are not only useless for the cells of the body, but could even be harmful. These waste byproducts are therefore needed to be removed from the body and discarded outside by a process called excretion. Again, if the basic rules for body design in multi-cellular organisms are followed, a specialised tissue for excretion will be developed, which means that the transportation system will need to transport waste away from cells to this excretory tissue.

Let us consider these various processes, so essential to maintain life, one by one.

## 5.2 NUTRITION

When we walk or ride a bicycle, we are using up energy. Even when we are not doing any apparent activity, energy is needed to maintain a state of order in our body. We also need materials from outside in order to grow, develop, synthesise protein and other substances needed in the body. This source of energy and materials is the food we eat.

### How do living things get their food?

The general requirement for energy and materials is common in all organisms, but it is fulfilled in different ways. Some organisms use simple food material obtained from inorganic sources in the form of carbon dioxide and water. These organisms, the autotrophs, include green plants and some bacteria. Other organisms utilise complex substances. These complex substances have to be broken down into simpler ones before they can be used for the upkeep and growth of the body. To achieve this, organisms use bio-catalysts called enzymes. Thus, the heterotrophs survival depends directly or indirectly on autotrophs. Heterotrophic organisms include animals and fungi.

## 5.2.1 Autotrophic Nutrition

Carbon and energy requirements of the autotrophic organism are fulfilled by photosynthesis. It is the process by which autotrophs take in substances from the outside and convert them into stored forms of energy. This material is taken in the form of carbon dioxide and water which is converted into carbohydrates in the presence of sunlight and chlorophyll. Carbohydrates are utilised for providing energy to the plant. We will study how this takes place in the next section. The carbohydrates which are not used immediately are stored in the form of starch, which serves as the internal energy reserve to be used as and when required by the plant. A somewhat similar situation is seen in us where some of the energy derived from the food we eat is stored in our body in the form of glycogen.

## 5.2.2 Heterotrophic Nutrition

Each organism is adapted to its environment. The form of nutrition differs depending on the type and availability of food material as well as how it is obtained by the organism. For example, whether the food source is stationary (such as grass) or mobile (such as a deer), would allow for differences in how the food is accessed and what is the nutritive apparatus used by a cow and a lion. There is a range of strategies by which the food is taken in and used by the organism. Some organisms break-down the food material outside the body and then absorb it. Examples are fungi like bread moulds, yeast and mushrooms. Others take in whole material and break it down inside their bodies. What can be taken in and broken down depends on the body design and functioning. Some other organisms derive nutrition from plants or animals without killing them. This parasitic nutritive strategy is used by a wide variety of organisms like cuscuta (amar-bel), ticks, lice, leeches and tape-worms.

We eat various types of food which has to pass through the same digestive tract. Naturally the food has to be processed to generate particles which are small and of the same texture. This is achieved by crushing the food with our teeth. Since the lining of the canal is soft, the food is also wetted to make its passage smooth. When we eat something we like, our mouth 'waters'. This is actually not only water, but a fluid called saliva secreted by the salivary glands. Another aspect of the food we ingest is its complex nature. If it is to be absorbed from the alimentary canal, it has to be broken into smaller molecules. This is done with the

help of biological catalysts called enzymes. The saliva contains an enzyme called salivary amylase that breaks down starch which is a complex molecule to give simple sugar. The food is mixed thoroughly with saliva and moved around the mouth while chewing by the muscular tongue.

It is necessary to move the food in a regulated manner along the digestive tube so that it can be processed properly in each part. The lining of canal has muscles that contract rhythmically in order to push the food forward. These peristaltic movements occur all along the gut.

From the mouth, the food is taken to the stomach through the food-pipe or oesophagus. The stomach is a large organ which expands when food enters it. The muscular walls of the stomach help in mixing the food thoroughly with more digestive juices.

The digestion in stomach is taken care of by the gastric glands present in the wall of the stomach. These release hydrochloric acid, a protein digesting enzyme called pepsin, and mucus. The hydrochloric acid creates an acidic medium which facilitates the action of the enzyme pepsin. What other function do you think is served by the acid? The mucus protects the inner lining of the stomach from the action of the acid under normal conditions. We

The exit of food from the stomach is regulated by a sphincter muscle which releases it in small amounts into the small intestine. From the stomach, the food now enters the small intestine. This is the longest part of the alimentary canal which is fitted into a compact space because of extensive coiling. The length of the small intestine differs in various animals depending on the food they eat. Herbivores eating grass need a longer small intestine to allow the cellulose to be digested. Meat is easier to digest, hence carnivores like tigers have a shorter small intestine.

The small intestine is the site of the complete digestion of carbohydrates, proteins and fats. It receives the secretions of the liver and pancreas for this purpose. The food coming from the stomach is acidic and has to be made alkaline for the pancreatic enzymes to act. Bile juice from the liver accomplishes this in addition to acting on fats. Fats are present in the intestine in the form of large globules which makes it difficult for enzymes to act on them. Bile salts break them down into smaller globules increasing the efficiency of enzyme action. This is similar to the emulsifying action of soaps on dirt that we have learnt about in Chapter 4. The pancreas secretes pancreatic juice which contains enzymes like trypsin for digesting proteins and lipase for breaking down emulsified fats. The walls of the small intestine contain glands which secrete intestinal juice. The enzymes present in it finally convert the proteins to amino acids, complex carbohydrates into glucose and fats into fatty acids and glycerol.

Digested food is taken up by the walls of the intestine. The inner lining of the small intestine has numerous finger-like projections called villi which increase the surface area for absorption. The villi are richly supplied with blood vessels which take the absorbed food to each and every cell of the body, where it is utilised for obtaining energy, building up new tissues and the repair of old tissues.

The unabsorbed food is sent into the large intestine where its wall absorb more water from this material. The rest of the material is removed from the body via the anus. The exit of this waste material is regulated by the anal sphincter.

# Dental caries

Dental caries or tooth decay causes gradual softening of enamel and dentine. It begins when bacteria acting on sugars produce acids that softens or demineralises the enamel. Masses of bacterial cells together with food particles stick to the teeth to form dental plaque. Saliva cannot reach the tooth surface to neutralise the acid as plaque covers the teeth. Brushing the teeth after eating removes the plaque before the bacteria produce acids. If untreated, microorganisms may invade the pulp, causing inflammation and infection.

We have discussed nutrition in organisms in the last section. The food material taken in during the process of nutrition is used in cells to provide energy for various life processes. Diverse organisms do this in different ways – some use oxygen to break-down glucose completely into carbon dioxide and water, some use other pathways that do not involve oxygen (Fig. 5.8). In all cases, the first step is the break-down of glucose, a six-carbon molecule, into a three-carbon molecule called pyruvate. This process takes place in the cytoplasm. Further, the pyruvate may be converted into ethanol and carbon dioxide. This process takes place in yeast during fermentation. Since this process takes place in the absence of air (oxygen), it is called anaerobic respiration. Breakdown of pyruvate using oxygen takes place in the mitochondria. This process breaks up the three-carbon pyruvate molecule to give three molecules of carbon dioxide. The other product is water. Since this process takes place in the presence of air (oxygen), it is called aerobic respiration. The release of energy in this aerobic process is a lot greater than in the anaerobic process. Sometimes, when there is a lack of oxygen in our muscle cells, another pathway for the break-down of pyruvate is taken. Here the pyruvate is converted into lactic acid which is also a three-carbon molecule. This build-up of lactic acid in our muscles during sudden activity causes cramps.

The energy released during cellular respiration is immediately used to synthesise a molecule called ATP which is used to fuel all other activities in the cell. In these processes, ATP is broken down giving rise to a fixed amount of energy which can drive the endothermic reactions taking place in the cell.

# ATP

ATP is the energy currency for most cellular processes. The energy released during the process of respiration is used to make an ATP molecule from ADP and inorganic phosphate.

Endothermic processes in the cell then use this ATP to drive the reactions. When the terminal phosphate linkage in ATP is broken using water, the energy equivalent to 30.5 kJ/mol is released.

Think of how a battery can provide energy for many different kinds of uses. It can be used to obtain mechanical energy, light energy, electrical energy and so on. Similarly, ATP can be used in the cells for the contraction of muscles, protein synthesis, conduction of nervous impulses and many other activities.

> Since the aerobic respiration pathway depends on oxygen, aerobic organisms need to ensure that there is sufficient intake of oxygen. We have seen that plants exchange gases through stomata, and the large inter-cellular spaces ensure that all cells are in contact with air. Carbon dioxide and oxygen are exchanged by diffusion here. They can go into

cells, or away from them and out into the air. The direction of diffusion depends upon the environmental conditions and the requirements of the plant. At night, when there is no photosynthesis occurring, CO<sup>2</sup> elimination is the major exchange activity going on. During the day, CO<sup>2</sup> generated during respiration is used up for photosynthesis, hence there is no CO<sup>2</sup> release. Instead, oxygen release is the major event at this time.

Animals have evolved different organs for the uptake of oxygen from the environment and for getting rid of the carbon dioxide produced. Terrestrial animals can breathe the oxygen in the atmosphere, but animals that live in water need to use the oxygen dissolved in water.

Since the amount of dissolved oxygen is fairly low compared to the amount of oxygen in the air, the rate of breathing in aquatic organisms is much faster than that seen in terrestrial organisms. Fishes take in water through their mouths and force it past the gills where the dissolved oxygen is taken up by blood.

Terrestrial organisms use the oxygen in the atmosphere for respiration. This oxygen is absorbed by different organs in different animals. All these organs have a structure that increases the surface area which is in contact with the oxygen-rich atmosphere. Since the exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide has to take place across this surface, this surface is very fine and delicate. In order to protect this surface, it is usually placed within the body, so there have to be passages that will take air to this area. In addition, there is a mechanism for moving the air in and out of this area where the oxygen is absorbed.

In human beings (Fig. 5.9), air is taken into the body through the nostrils. The air passing through the nostrils is filtered by fine hairs that line the passage. The passage is also lined with mucus which helps in this process. From here, the air passes through the throat and into the lungs. Rings of cartilage are present in the throat. These ensure that the air-passage does not collapse.

Smoking is injurious to health.

Lung cancer is one of common causes of deaths in the world. The upper part of respiratory tract is provided with small hair -like structures called cilia. These cilia help to remove germs, dust and other harmful particles from inhaled air. Smoking destroys these hair due to which germs, dust, smoke and other harmful chemicals enter lungs and cause infection, cough and even lung cancer.

Within the lungs, the passage divides into smaller and smaller tubes which finally terminate in balloon-like structures which are called alveoli (singular–alveolus). The alveoli provide a surface where the exchange of gases can take place. The walls of the alveoli contain an extensive network of blood-vessels. As we have seen in earlier years, when we breathe in, we lift our ribs and flatten our diaphragm, and the chest cavity becomes larger as a result. Because of this, air is sucked into the lungs and fills the expanded alveoli. The blood brings carbon dioxide from the rest of the body for release into the alveoli, and the oxygen in the alveolar air is taken up by blood in the alveolar blood vessels to be transported to all the cells in the body. During the breathing cycle, when air is taken in and let out, the lungs always contain a residual volume of air so that there is sufficient time for oxygen to be absorbed and for the carbon dioxide to be released.

When the body size of animals is large, the diffusion pressure alone cannot take care of oxygen delivery to all parts of the body. Instead, respiratory pigments take up oxygen from the air in the lungs and carry it to tissues which are deficient in oxygen before releasing it. In human beings, the respiratory pigment is haemoglobin which has a very high affinity for oxygen. This pigment is present in the red blood corpuscles. Carbon dioxide is more soluble in water than oxygen is and hence is mostly transported in the dissolved form in our blood.

#### Our pump — the heart

The heart is a muscular organ which is as big as our fist (Fig. 5.10). Because both oxygen and carbon dioxide have to be transported by the blood, the heart has different chambers to prevent the oxygen-rich blood from mixing with the blood containing carbon dioxide. The carbon dioxide-rich blood has to reach the lungs for the carbon dioxide to be removed, and the oxygenated blood from the lungs has to be brought back to the heart. This oxygen-rich blood is then pumped to the rest of the body.

We can follow this process step by step (Fig. 5.11). Oxygen-rich blood from the lungs comes to the thin-walled upper

chamber of the heart on the left, the left atrium. The left atrium relaxes when it is collecting this blood. It then contracts, while the next chamber, the left ventricle, relaxes, so that the blood is transferred to it. When the muscular left ventricle contracts in its turn, the blood is pumped out to the body. De-oxygenated blood comes from the body to the upper chamber on the right, the right atrium, as it relaxes. As the right atrium contracts, the corresponding lower chamber, the right ventricle, dilates. This transfers blood to the right ventricle, which in turn pumps it to the lungs for oxygenation. Since ventricles have to pump blood into various organs, they have thicker muscular walls than the atria do. Valves ensure that blood does not flow backwards when the atria or ventricles contract.

#### Oxygen enters the blood in the lungs

The separation of the right side and the left side of the heart is useful to keep oxygenated and deoxygenated blood from mixing. Such separation allows a highly efficient supply of oxygen to the body. This is useful in animals that have high energy needs, such as birds and mammals, which constantly use energy to maintain their body temperature. In animals that do not use energy for this purpose, the body temperature depends on the temperature in the environment. Such animals, like amphibians or many reptiles have three-chambered hearts, and tolerate some mixing of the oxygenated and de-oxygenated blood streams. Fishes, on the other hand, have only two chambers to their hearts, and the blood is pumped to the gills, is oxygenated there, and passes directly to the rest of the body. Thus, blood goes only once through the heart in the fish during one cycle of

passage through the body. On the other hand, it goes through the heart twice during each cycle in other vertebrates. This is known as double circulation.

#### Blood pressure

The force that blood exerts against the wall of a vessel is called blood pressure. This pressure is much greater in arteries than in veins. The pressure of blood inside the artery during ventricular systole (contraction) is called systolic pressure and pressure in artery during ventricular diastole (relaxation) is called diastolic pressure. The normal systolic pressure is about 120 mm of Hg and diastolic pressure is 80 mm of Hg.

![](_page_14_Figure_4.jpeg)

Blood pressure is measured with an instrument called sphygmomanometer. High blood pressure is also called hypertension and is caused by the constriction of arterioles, which results in increased resistance to blood flow. It can lead to the rupture of an artery and internal bleeding.

#### The tubes – blood vessels

Arteries are the vessels which carry blood away from the heart to various organs of the body. Since the blood emerges from the heart under high pressure, the arteries have thick, elastic walls. Veins collect the blood from different organs and bring it back to the heart. They do not need thick walls because the blood is no longer under pressure, instead they have valves that ensure that the blood flows only in one direction.

On reaching an organ or tissue, the artery divides into smaller and smaller vessels to bring the blood in contact with all the individual cells. The smallest vessels have walls which are one-cell thick and are called capillaries. Exchange of material between the blood and surrounding cells takes place across this thin wall. The capillaries then join together to form veins that convey the blood away from the organ or tissue.

#### Maintenance by platelets

What happens if this system of tubes develops a leak? Think about situations when we are injured and start bleeding. Naturally the loss of blood from the system has to be minimised. In addition, leakage would lead to a loss of pressure which would reduce the efficiency of the

pumping system. To avoid this, the blood has platelet cells which circulate around the body and plug these leaks by helping to clot the blood at these points of injury.

#### Lymph

There is another type of fluid also involved in transportation. This is called lymph or tissue fluid. Through the pores present in the walls of capillaries some amount of plasma, proteins and blood cells escape into intercellular spaces in the tissues to form the tissue fluid or lymph. It is similar to the plasma of blood but colourless and contains less protein. Lymph drains into lymphatic capillaries from the intercellular spaces, which join to form large lymph vessels that finally open into larger veins. Lymph carries digested and absorbed fat from intestine and drains excess fluid from extra cellular space back into the blood.

### 5.4.2 Transportation in Plants

We have discussed earlier how plants take in simple compounds such as CO<sup>2</sup> and photosynthesise energy stored in their chlorophyll-containing organs, namely leaves. The other kinds of raw materials needed for building plant bodies will also have to be taken up separately. For plants, the soil is the nearest and richest source of raw materials like nitrogen, phosphorus and other minerals. The absorption of these substances therefore occurs through the part in contact with the soil, namely roots. If the distances between soil-contacting organs and chlorophyllcontaining organs are small, energy and raw materials can easily diffuse to all parts of the plant body. But if these distances become large because of changes in plant body design, diffusion processes will not be sufficient to provide raw material in leaves and energy in roots. A proper system of transportation is therefore essential in such situations.

Energy needs differ between different body designs. Plants do not move, and plant bodies have a large proportion of dead cells in many tissues. As a result, plants have low energy needs, and can use relatively slow transport systems. The distances over which transport systems have to operate, however, can be very large in plants such as very tall trees.

Plant transport systems will move energy stores from leaves and raw materials from roots. These two pathways are constructed as independently organised conducting tubes. One, the xylem moves water and minerals obtained from the soil. The other, phloem transports products of photosynthesis from the leaves where they are synthesised to other parts of the plant. We have studied the structure of these tissues in detail in Class IX.

#### Transport of water

In xylem tissue, vessels and tracheids of the roots, stems and leaves are interconnected to form a continuous system of water-conducting channels reaching all parts of the plant. At the roots, cells in contact with the soil actively take up ions. This creates a difference in the concentration of these ions between the root and the soil. Water, therefore, moves into the root from the soil to eliminate this difference. This means that there is steady movement of water into root xylem, creating a column of water that is steadily pushed upwards.

However, this pressure by itself is unlikely to be enough to move water over the heights that we commonly see in plants. Plants use another strategy to move water in the xylem upwards to the highest points of the plant body.

Provided that the plant has an adequate supply of water, the water which is lost through the stomata is replaced by water from the xylem vessels in the leaf. In fact, evaporation of water molecules from the cells of a leaf creates a suction which pulls water from the xylem cells of roots. The loss of water in the form of vapour from the aerial parts of the plant is known as transpiration.

Thus, transpiration helps in the absorption and upward movement of water and minerals dissolved in it from roots to the leaves. It also helps in temperature regulation. The effect of root pressure in transport of water is more important at night. During the day when the stomata are open, the transpiration pull becomes the major driving force in the movement of water in the xylem.

#### Transport of food and other substances

So far we have discussed the transport of water and minerals in plants. Now let us consider how the products of metabolic processes, particularly photosynthesis, are moved from leaves, where they are formed, to other parts of the plant. This transport of soluble products of photosynthesis is called translocation and it occurs in the part of the vascular tissue known as phloem. Besides the products of photosynthesis, the phloem transports amino acids and other substances. These substances are especially delivered to the storage organs of roots, fruits and seeds and to growing organs. The translocation of food and other substances takes place in the sieve tubes with the help of adjacent companion cells both in upward and downward directions.

Unlike transport in xylem which can be largely explained by simple physical forces, the translocation in phloem is achieved by utilising energy. Material like sucrose is transferred into phloem tissue using energy from ATP. This increases the osmotic pressure of the tissue causing water to move into it. This pressure moves the material in the phloem to tissues which have less pressure. This allows the phloem to move material according to the plant's needs. For example, in the spring, sugar stored in root or stem tissue would be transported to the buds which need energy to grow.

## 5.5 EXCRETION CRETION

We have already discussed how organisms get rid of gaseous wastes generated during photosynthesis or respiration. Other metabolic activities generate nitrogenous materials which need to be removed. The biological process involved in the removal of these harmful metabolic wastes from the body is called excretion. Different organisms use varied strategies to do this. Many unicellular organisms remove these wastes by simple

Figure 5.13 *Excretory system in human beings*

diffusion from the body surface into the surrounding water. As we have seen in other processes, complex multi-cellular organisms use specialised organs to perform the same function.

## 5.5.1 Excretion in Human Beings

The excretory system of human beings (Fig. 5.13) includes a pair of kidneys, a pair of ureters, a urinary bladder and a urethra. Kidneys are located in the abdomen, one on either side of the backbone. Urine produced in the kidneys passes through the ureters into the urinary bladder where it is stored until it is released through the urethra.

How is urine produced? The purpose of making urine is to filter out waste products from the blood. Just as CO<sup>2</sup> is removed from the blood in the lungs, nitrogenous waste such as urea or uric acid are removed from blood in the kidneys. It is then no surprise that the basic filtration unit in the kidneys, like in the lungs, is a cluster of very thin-walled blood capillaries. Each capillary cluster in the kidney is associated with the cup-shaped end of a coiled tube called Bowman's capsule that collects the filtrate (Fig. 5.14). Each kidney has large numbers of these filtration units called nephrons packed close together. Some substances in the initial filtrate, such as glucose, amino acids, salts and a major amount of water, are selectively re-absorbed as the urine flows along the tube. The amount of water re-absorbed depends on how much excess water there is in the body, and on how much of dissolved waste there is to be excreted. The urine forming in each kidney eventually enters a long tube, the ureter, which connects the kidneys with the urinary bladder. Urine is stored in the urinary bladder until the pressure of the expanded bladder leads to the urge to pass it out through the urethra. The bladder is muscular, so it is under nervous control, as we have discussed elsewhere. As a result, we can usually control the urge to urinate.

#### Artificial kidney (Hemodialysis)

Kidneys are vital organs for survival. Several factors like infections, injury or restricted blood flow to kidneys reduce the activity of kidneys. This leads to accumulation of poisonous wastes in the body, which can even lead to death. In case of kidney failure, an artificial kidney can be used. An artificial kidney is a device to remove nitrogenous waste products from the blood through *dialysis.*

Artificial kidneys contain a number of tubes with a semi-permeable lining, suspended

![](_page_18_Figure_8.jpeg)

in a tank filled with dialysing fluid. This fluid has the same osmotic pressure as blood, except that it is devoid of nitrogenous wastes. The patient's blood is passed through these tubes. During this passage, the waste products from the blood pass into dialysing fluid by diffusion. The purified blood is pumped back into the patient. This is similar to the function of the kidney, but it is different since there is no reabsorption involved. Normally, in a healthy adult, the initial filtrate in the kidneys is about 180 L daily. However, the volume actually excreted is only a litre or two a day, because the remaining filtrate is reabsorbed in the kidney tubules.

### Think it over!

#### Organ donation

Organ donation is a generous act of donating an organ to a person who suffers from non-function of organ(s). Donation of an organ may be done by the consent of the donor and his/her family. Anyone regardless of age or gender can become an organ and tissue donor. Organ transplants can save or transform the life of a person. Transplantation is required because recipient's organ has been damaged or has failed by disease or injury. In organ transplantation the organ is surgically removed from one person (organ donor) and transplanted to another person (the recipient). Common transplantations include corneas, kidneys, heart, liver, pancreas, lungs, intestines and bone marrow. Most organ and tissue donations occur just after the donor has died or when the doctor declares a person brain dead. But some organs such as kidney, part of a liver, lung, etc., and tissues can be donated while the donor is alive.

## 5.5.2 Excretion in Plants

Plants use completely different strategies for excretion than those of animals. Oxygen itself can be thought of as a waste product generated during photosynthesis! We have discussed earlier how plants deal with oxygen as well as CO<sup>2</sup> . They can get rid of excess water by transpiration. For other wastes, plants use the fact that many of their tissues consist of dead cells, and that they can even lose some parts such as leaves. Many plant waste products are stored in cellular vacuoles. Waste products may be stored in leaves that fall off. Other waste products are stored as resins and gums, especially in old xylem. Plants also excrete some waste substances into the soil around them.

exercises.question: Why is diffusion insufficient to meet the oxygen requirements of multicellular organisms like humans?
exercises.answer: Diffusion is insufficient for multicellular organisms like humans because: 1) Diffusion is a slow process that works effectively only over short distances. 2) In large multicellular organisms, many cells are located far from the surface and cannot directly exchange gases with the environment. 3) The body's oxygen demand is high due to active metabolism, requiring rapid and efficient oxygen delivery. 4) Simple diffusion would take an extremely long time - it's estimated that it would take 3 years for oxygen to reach our toes from our lungs through diffusion alone. Therefore, specialized respiratory and circulatory systems with respiratory pigments like hemoglobin are necessary for efficient oxygen transport.

exercises.question: What criteria do we use to decide whether something is alive?
exercises.answer: We use several criteria to determine if something is alive: 1) Movement - both visible movement and invisible molecular movement within cells. 2) Growth - increase in size or development over time. 3) Breathing or gas exchange - taking in oxygen and releasing carbon dioxide. 4) Response to stimuli - reacting to environmental changes. 5) Maintenance processes - continuous repair and upkeep of body structures. The key indicator is molecular movement, as living organisms must constantly move molecules to maintain their organized structures and perform life processes. Even when organisms appear inactive (like sleeping animals or non-growing plants), molecular movements continue to sustain life.

exercises.question: What are outside raw materials used for by an organism?
exercises.answer: Outside raw materials are used by organisms for: 1) Energy production - food sources are broken down to release energy for cellular processes and ATP synthesis. 2) Growth and development - raw materials provide building blocks for new tissues and body parts. 3) Maintenance and repair - materials are needed to replace damaged or worn-out cellular components. 4) Synthesis of essential compounds - raw materials are used to make proteins, enzymes, hormones, and other vital molecules. 5) Structural components - materials like carbon, nitrogen, phosphorus are incorporated into cell walls, membranes, and other structures. These materials must be processed and converted into forms that the organism can use effectively.

exercises.question: What processes would you consider essential for maintaining life?
exercises.answer: The essential life processes for maintaining life are: 1) Nutrition - obtaining and processing food for energy and raw materials. 2) Respiration - breaking down food molecules to release energy and exchange of gases (oxygen intake, carbon dioxide removal). 3) Transportation - moving materials like nutrients, oxygen, and waste products throughout the body. 4) Excretion - removing harmful waste products from metabolic processes. 5) Growth and repair - building new tissues and maintaining existing structures. These processes work together continuously to maintain the organized structure of living organisms and provide energy for all cellular activities, even when the organism appears to be at rest.

exercises.question: What are the differences between autotrophic nutrition and heterotrophic nutrition?
exercises.answer: Autotrophic nutrition: 1) Organisms make their own food from simple inorganic materials (CO₂, water). 2) Uses external energy source (sunlight in photosynthesis). 3) Produces complex organic molecules from simple ones. 4) Examples: green plants, some bacteria. 5) Independent food production. Heterotrophic nutrition: 1) Organisms obtain food from other organisms or complex organic sources. 2) Cannot synthesize food from inorganic materials. 3) Breaks down complex substances into simpler ones. 4) Examples: animals, fungi, most bacteria. 5) Depends directly or indirectly on autotrophs for food. 6) Uses enzymes (bio-catalysts) to break down complex food materials.

exercises.question: Where do plants get each of the raw materials required for photosynthesis?
exercises.answer: Plants obtain raw materials for photosynthesis from different sources: 1) Carbon dioxide - absorbed from the atmosphere through stomata (tiny pores) on leaves. 2) Water - absorbed from soil by roots and transported through xylem to leaves. 3) Sunlight - captured by chlorophyll in chloroplasts. 4) Chlorophyll - synthesized by the plant itself, present in chloroplasts. Additionally, plants obtain other essential materials: 5) Minerals like nitrogen, phosphorus, iron, magnesium - absorbed from soil through roots. 6) Nitrogen - taken up as inorganic nitrates/nitrites or organic compounds prepared by bacteria from atmospheric nitrogen. These materials are transported through the plant's vascular system to where they are needed.

exercises.question: What is the role of the acid in our stomach?
exercises.answer: Hydrochloric acid in the stomach serves several important roles: 1) Creates acidic medium (low pH) - This is essential for the proper functioning of pepsin, the protein-digesting enzyme that works optimally in acidic conditions. 2) Kills harmful microorganisms - The strong acid destroys bacteria and other pathogens that enter with food, providing protection against infections. 3) Activates pepsinogen - Converts the inactive enzyme pepsinogen into active pepsin. 4) Aids protein digestion - Helps denature proteins, making them easier to digest. 5) Facilitates mineral absorption - Helps in the absorption of certain minerals like iron and vitamin B12. The stomach lining produces mucus to protect itself from this strong acid under normal conditions.

exercises.question: What is the function of digestive enzymes?
exercises.answer: Digestive enzymes are biological catalysts that perform crucial functions: 1) Break down complex food molecules - Convert large, complex substances into smaller, simpler molecules that can be absorbed. 2) Specific substrate action - Each enzyme works on specific types of food (e.g., amylase on starch, pepsin on proteins, lipase on fats). 3) Speed up digestion - Catalyze chemical reactions, making digestion much faster than it would be naturally. 4) Enable absorption - Convert food into forms that can pass through intestinal walls into blood. Examples: Salivary amylase breaks starch into simple sugars, pepsin breaks proteins into smaller peptides, trypsin further breaks proteins, lipase breaks fats into fatty acids and glycerol. Without enzymes, digestion would be too slow to meet the body's energy needs.

exercises.question: How is the small intestine designed to absorb digested food?
exercises.answer: The small intestine has several design features that maximize absorption: 1) Length - It's the longest part of the alimentary canal, providing maximum time for absorption. 2) Villi - The inner lining has numerous finger-like projections called villi that greatly increase the surface area for absorption. 3) Thin walls - Villi have very thin walls that allow easy passage of digested food molecules. 4) Rich blood supply - Villi are richly supplied with blood vessels that quickly transport absorbed nutrients to all body cells. 5) Coiled structure - Extensive coiling fits the long intestine into a compact space while maintaining length. 6) Complete digestion site - Final breakdown of carbohydrates to glucose, proteins to amino acids, and fats to fatty acids and glycerol occurs here. This design ensures maximum absorption efficiency of digested nutrients.

exercises.question: What advantage over an aquatic organism does a terrestrial organism have with regard to obtaining oxygen for respiration?
exercises.answer: Terrestrial organisms have several advantages over aquatic organisms for obtaining oxygen: 1) Higher oxygen concentration - Air contains about 21% oxygen, while water has much lower dissolved oxygen content. 2) Easier oxygen access - Oxygen is readily available in the atmosphere and doesn't need to be extracted from water. 3) Lower breathing rate - Due to higher oxygen availability, terrestrial organisms can breathe more slowly compared to aquatic organisms that must breathe rapidly to extract sufficient dissolved oxygen. 4) More efficient gas exchange - Air-breathing organs like lungs can extract oxygen more efficiently than gills extracting from water. 5) No water resistance - Air is less dense than water, making breathing movements easier and less energy-consuming. This is why fish open and close their mouths much more frequently than terrestrial animals breathe.

exercises.question: What are the different ways in which glucose is oxidised to provide energy in various organisms?
exercises.answer: Glucose is oxidized through different pathways: 1) Aerobic respiration - In presence of oxygen, glucose is completely broken down in mitochondria to produce CO₂, water, and maximum ATP (about 38 molecules). This occurs in most plants and animals. 2) Anaerobic respiration (Fermentation) - In absence of oxygen: a) Alcoholic fermentation - In yeast, glucose breaks down to ethanol and CO₂ (used in brewing and baking). b) Lactic acid fermentation - In muscle cells during intense exercise, glucose converts to lactic acid, causing cramps. 3) First step common to all - Glucose first breaks down to pyruvate in cytoplasm (glycolysis). 4) Energy yield varies - Aerobic respiration produces much more energy than anaerobic processes. The pathway chosen depends on oxygen availability and the organism's metabolic needs.

exercises.question: How is oxygen and carbon dioxide transported in human beings?
exercises.answer: Oxygen and carbon dioxide are transported differently in humans: Oxygen transport: 1) Hemoglobin binding - Oxygen binds to hemoglobin in red blood cells forming oxyhemoglobin. 2) High affinity - Hemoglobin has very high affinity for oxygen, ensuring efficient pickup in lungs. 3) Delivery system - Oxyhemoglobin releases oxygen to tissues with low oxygen concentration. Carbon dioxide transport: 1) Dissolved form - Most CO₂ is transported dissolved in blood plasma (since CO₂ is more water-soluble than oxygen). 2) Bicarbonate form - Some CO₂ combines with water to form bicarbonate ions. 3) Hemoglobin binding - Small amount binds to hemoglobin. 4) Reverse process - In lungs, CO₂ is released and oxygen is picked up. This system ensures efficient gas exchange and transport throughout the body.

exercises.question: How are the lungs designed in human beings to maximise the area for exchange of gases?
exercises.answer: The lungs have several design features that maximize gas exchange area: 1) Alveolar structure - Air passages end in balloon-like structures called alveoli, providing enormous surface area. 2) Large surface area - If spread out, alveolar surface would cover about 80 m² (much larger than body surface area). 3) Thin walls - Alveolar walls are extremely thin (one-cell thick) allowing easy diffusion of gases. 4) Rich blood supply - Extensive network of blood capillaries surrounds each alveolus for efficient gas exchange. 5) Moist surface - Alveolar walls are moist, facilitating gas dissolution and exchange. 6) Branching pattern - Airways branch repeatedly into smaller tubes, creating millions of alveoli. 7) Residual volume - Lungs always contain some air, ensuring continuous gas exchange even between breaths. This design makes gas exchange extremely efficient despite the body's high oxygen demands.

exercises.question: What are the components of the transport system in human beings? What are the functions of these components?
exercises.answer: The human transport system consists of: 1) Heart - Muscular pumping organ with four chambers (two atria, two ventricles). Functions: pumps blood throughout the body, separates oxygenated and deoxygenated blood, maintains blood pressure. 2) Blood vessels: a) Arteries - thick-walled vessels carrying blood away from heart under high pressure. b) Veins - thin-walled vessels with valves, returning blood to heart. c) Capillaries - microscopic vessels with thin walls for material exchange between blood and tissues. 3) Blood - fluid containing plasma, RBCs, WBCs, platelets. Functions: transports oxygen (via hemoglobin), nutrients, hormones, waste products; provides immunity; clots at injury sites. 4) Lymphatic system - network of lymph vessels and nodes. Functions: drains excess tissue fluid, transports fats from intestine, provides immunity. Together, these components ensure efficient circulation and transport of materials throughout the body.

exercises.question: Why is it necessary to separate oxygenated and deoxygenated blood in mammals and birds?
exercises.answer: Separation of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood is necessary in mammals and birds because: 1) High energy demands - These animals are warm-blooded (endothermic) and constantly use energy to maintain body temperature, requiring highly efficient oxygen supply. 2) Complete separation ensures maximum efficiency - Prevents mixing of oxygen-rich and oxygen-poor blood, ensuring tissues receive blood with maximum oxygen content. 3) Four-chambered heart - Allows complete separation with left side handling oxygenated blood and right side handling deoxygenated blood. 4) Double circulation - Blood passes through heart twice in each cycle, once to lungs for oxygenation and once to body tissues. 5) Comparison with other animals - Cold-blooded animals like amphibians and reptiles can tolerate some mixing (three-chambered heart) as they have lower energy needs. Fish have two-chambered hearts with single circulation. This efficient system supports the high metabolic rate required for maintaining constant body temperature.

exercises.question: What are the components of the transport system in highly organised plants?
exercises.answer: The transport system in highly organized plants consists of vascular tissues: 1) Xylem - composed of vessels and tracheids. Functions: transports water and dissolved minerals from roots to all parts of the plant; provides structural support; forms continuous water-conducting channels throughout the plant. 2) Phloem - composed of sieve tubes and companion cells. Functions: transports products of photosynthesis (mainly sucrose) from leaves to other parts; transports amino acids and other organic substances; can transport materials both upward and downward as per plant's needs. 3) Supporting structures: Root system for absorption, leaf system for photosynthesis, stem system connecting roots and leaves. 4) Differences from animal systems: Plant transport is slower due to lower energy needs; plants don't move and have many dead cells; transport works over very large distances in tall trees; no pumping organ like heart - uses physical forces and energy from ATP. These systems work independently but coordinately to meet the plant's nutritional and structural needs.

exercises.question: How are water and minerals transported in plants?
exercises.answer: Water and mineral transport in plants occurs through xylem via several mechanisms: 1) Root absorption - Root cells actively take up minerals from soil, creating concentration difference that draws water into roots by osmosis. 2) Root pressure - Continuous water uptake creates pressure that pushes water upward in xylem vessels. 3) Transpiration pull - Major driving force during day; water evaporation from leaves creates suction that pulls water up from roots through xylem. 4) Continuous water column - Xylem vessels and tracheids form interconnected water-conducting channels from roots to leaves. 5) Cohesion-tension theory - Water molecules stick together, creating continuous water column that can be pulled upward. 6) Day-night variation - Root pressure more important at night when stomata are closed; transpiration pull dominates during day when stomata are open. 7) Mineral transport - Dissolved minerals are carried along with water through the same xylem pathway. This system can transport water to great heights in tall trees efficiently.

exercises.question: How is food transported in plants?
exercises.answer: Food transport in plants occurs through phloem in a process called translocation: 1) Source to sink - Food (mainly sucrose) moves from source organs (leaves where photosynthesis occurs) to sink organs (roots, fruits, seeds, growing parts). 2) Phloem structure - Sieve tubes with companion cells form the transport pathway for food materials. 3) Energy-dependent process - Unlike xylem transport, phloem transport requires energy from ATP. 4) Loading mechanism - Sucrose is actively loaded into phloem tissue using ATP energy, increasing osmotic pressure. 5) Pressure flow - High osmotic pressure causes water to enter phloem, creating pressure that moves materials to areas of lower pressure. 6) Bidirectional transport - Can move materials both upward and downward depending on plant needs. 7) Seasonal variation - In spring, stored food in roots/stems is transported to growing buds. 8) Multiple substances - Transports not only sugars but also amino acids and other organic compounds. This system efficiently distributes photosynthetic products according to the plant's metabolic and growth requirements.

exercises.question: Describe the structure and functioning of nephrons.
exercises.answer: Nephrons are the functional units of kidneys with specific structure and functions: Structure: 1) Bowman's capsule - Cup-shaped structure that collects filtrate from blood. 2) Glomerulus - Cluster of thin-walled blood capillaries inside Bowman's capsule where filtration occurs. 3) Tubular system - Long coiled tube where filtrate is processed. 4) Collecting duct - Final part where urine is concentrated. Functioning: 1) Filtration - Blood pressure forces water, salts, glucose, amino acids, and urea from glomerulus into Bowman's capsule. 2) Selective reabsorption - Useful substances like glucose, amino acids, salts, and most water are reabsorbed back into blood as filtrate moves through tubule. 3) Concentration - Amount of water reabsorbed depends on body's water balance and waste concentration needs. 4) Urine formation - Final filtrate becomes urine containing urea, excess salts, and water. 5) Regulation - Nervous system controls the process based on body's needs. Each kidney contains millions of nephrons working together to filter blood and maintain body's chemical balance.

exercises.question: What are the methods used by plants to get rid of excretory products?
exercises.answer: Plants use various strategies to eliminate waste products: 1) Gas exchange - Oxygen (waste from photosynthesis) and CO₂ (waste from respiration) are removed through stomata. 2) Transpiration - Excess water is eliminated as water vapor through stomata and leaf surfaces. 3) Leaf fall - Many waste products are stored in leaves that eventually fall off, removing wastes from the plant. 4) Storage in dead tissues - Wastes are stored in dead xylem tissue as resins and gums, which don't harm the plant. 5) Cellular vacuoles - Waste materials are stored in cell vacuoles, isolating them from active cellular processes. 6) Soil excretion - Some waste substances are excreted directly into surrounding soil through roots. 7) Bark and stem storage - Wastes may be deposited in bark and older stem tissues. 8) Fruit and seed disposal - Some wastes are eliminated when fruits are consumed and seeds dispersed. Plants can use these methods because they have many dead cells and can afford to lose parts like leaves, unlike animals that must actively excrete wastes.

exercises.question: How is the amount of urine produced regulated?
exercises.answer: Urine production is regulated through several mechanisms: 1) Water reabsorption control - The amount of water reabsorbed in kidney tubules varies based on body's water balance; more reabsorption when body needs water conservation, less when excess water needs elimination. 2) Antidiuretic hormone (ADH) - Released by pituitary gland when blood becomes concentrated; increases water reabsorption in kidneys, producing concentrated urine. 3) Blood pressure effects - Higher blood pressure increases filtration rate, producing more urine; lower pressure reduces urine production. 4) Dissolved waste concentration - When more wastes need excretion, less water is reabsorbed to dilute and eliminate wastes effectively. 5) Nervous control - Bladder filling triggers nerve signals that control urination urge and sphincter muscle function. 6) Daily variation - Normal filtrate formation is about 180L daily, but only 1-2L is excreted as urine due to selective reabsorption. 7) Environmental factors - Hot weather or exercise increases water loss through sweating, leading to more concentrated urine production. This regulation maintains proper water balance and waste elimination in the body.

exercises.question: The kidneys in human beings are a part of the system for (a) nutrition (b) respiration (c) excretion (d) transportation
exercises.answer: (c) excretion. The kidneys are the main organs of the excretory system in human beings. They filter blood to remove nitrogenous wastes like urea and uric acid, excess water, and salts, producing urine. The excretory system includes kidneys, ureters, urinary bladder, and urethra, all working together to eliminate waste products from the body and maintain proper water and chemical balance.

exercises.question: The xylem in plants are responsible for (a) transport of water (b) transport of food (c) transport of amino acids (d) transport of oxygen
exercises.answer: (a) transport of water. Xylem tissue in plants is specifically responsible for transporting water and dissolved minerals from the roots to all other parts of the plant. Xylem vessels and tracheids form a continuous system of water-conducting channels. Food transport is handled by phloem tissue, not xylem. While minerals dissolved in water are transported by xylem, the primary function is water transport driven by transpiration and root pressure.

exercises.question: The autotrophic mode of nutrition requires (a) carbon dioxide and water (b) chlorophyll (c) sunlight (d) all of the above
exercises.answer: (d) all of the above. Autotrophic nutrition (photosynthesis) requires all these components: carbon dioxide (from atmosphere), water (from soil), chlorophyll (to capture light energy), and sunlight (energy source). The process combines CO₂ and water in the presence of sunlight and chlorophyll to produce glucose and oxygen. Each component is essential - without any one of them, photosynthesis cannot occur.

exercises.question: The breakdown of pyruvate to give carbon dioxide, water and energy takes place in (a) cytoplasm (b) mitochondria (c) chloroplast (d) nucleus
exercises.answer: (b) mitochondria. The complete breakdown of pyruvate in the presence of oxygen (aerobic respiration) occurs in the mitochondria. This process produces carbon dioxide, water, and a large amount of energy (ATP). The initial breakdown of glucose to pyruvate occurs in the cytoplasm, but the final oxidation of pyruvate happens in the mitochondria, which are called the 'powerhouses of the cell' because they generate most of the cell's ATP.

exercises.question: How are fats digested in our bodies? Where does this process take place?
exercises.answer: Fat digestion occurs primarily in the small intestine through the following process: 1) Emulsification - Bile juice from the liver breaks large fat globules into smaller droplets, increasing surface area for enzyme action (similar to soap action on grease). 2) Enzymatic breakdown - Lipase enzyme from pancreatic juice breaks down emulsified fats into fatty acids and glycerol. 3) Location - This process takes place mainly in the small intestine, where bile from liver and pancreatic juice containing lipase act on fats. 4) Absorption - The broken-down products (fatty acids and glycerol) are absorbed by the intestinal walls. 5) Role of bile salts - Essential for fat digestion as they increase the efficiency of lipase enzyme action by creating smaller fat particles. Without bile, fat digestion would be very inefficient, leading to digestive problems.

exercises.question: What is the role of saliva in the digestion of food?
exercises.answer: Saliva plays several important roles in food digestion: 1) Moistening food - Saliva wets the food, making it easier to chew and swallow, and helps in smooth passage through the alimentary canal. 2) Enzymatic action - Contains salivary amylase enzyme that begins the breakdown of starch (complex carbohydrate) into simple sugars like maltose. 3) Lubrication - Helps in mixing food thoroughly and moving it around the mouth during chewing. 4) pH regulation - Provides appropriate pH for enzyme action and helps neutralize acids from food. 5) Antimicrobial action - Contains substances that help kill harmful bacteria entering with food. 6) Taste facilitation - Dissolves food particles, enabling taste buds to detect flavors. 7) Protective function - Helps clean the mouth and teeth. The digestive process actually begins in the mouth with saliva, making it the first step in chemical digestion.

exercises.question: What are the necessary conditions for autotrophic nutrition and what are its byproducts?
exercises.answer: Necessary conditions for autotrophic nutrition (photosynthesis): 1) Carbon dioxide - obtained from atmosphere through stomata. 2) Water - absorbed from soil by roots. 3) Sunlight - external energy source for the process. 4) Chlorophyll - green pigment present in chloroplasts that captures light energy. 5) Appropriate temperature - for optimal enzyme function. The process: 6CO₂ + 6H₂O + light energy (chlorophyll) → C₆H₁₂O₆ + 6O₂. Byproducts of photosynthesis: 1) Oxygen - released into atmosphere as a waste product (though essential for other organisms). 2) Water - produced during the process. 3) Glucose - primary product used for energy and stored as starch. Additional products: 4) Starch - stored form of glucose for future energy needs. This process is crucial as it converts inorganic materials into organic compounds and produces oxygen that supports most life on Earth.

exercises.question: What are the differences between aerobic and anaerobic respiration? Name some organisms that use the anaerobic mode of respiration.
exercises.answer: Differences between aerobic and anaerobic respiration: Aerobic respiration: 1) Requires oxygen. 2) Occurs in mitochondria. 3) Complete breakdown of glucose to CO₂ and water. 4) Produces about 38 ATP molecules per glucose. 5) End products: CO₂ and H₂O. Anaerobic respiration: 1) Occurs without oxygen. 2) Takes place in cytoplasm. 3) Incomplete breakdown of glucose. 4) Produces only 2 ATP molecules per glucose. 5) End products vary: ethanol + CO₂ (in yeast), lactic acid (in muscles). Organisms using anaerobic respiration: 1) Yeast - produces ethanol and CO₂ (used in brewing and baking). 2) Some bacteria - in oxygen-deficient environments. 3) Muscle cells - during intense exercise when oxygen supply is insufficient. 4) Some parasitic worms - living in oxygen-poor environments. 5) Certain fungi and microorganisms. Anaerobic respiration is less efficient but allows survival in oxygen-limited conditions.

exercises.question: How are the alveoli designed to maximise the exchange of gases?
exercises.answer: Alveoli are perfectly designed for maximum gas exchange efficiency: 1) Large surface area - Millions of alveoli provide enormous surface area (about 80 m² if spread flat), much larger than body surface area. 2) Thin walls - Alveolar walls are extremely thin (one-cell thick), allowing easy diffusion of gases between air and blood. 3) Rich blood supply - Each alveolus is surrounded by dense network of capillaries for efficient gas exchange. 4) Moist surface - Alveolar walls are moist, facilitating dissolution and diffusion of gases. 5) Balloon-like structure - Shape maximizes surface area while minimizing space. 6) Elastic walls - Allow expansion and contraction during breathing. 7) Strategic location - Located at the end of branched air passages, ensuring air reaches exchange surface. 8) Optimal thickness - Wall thickness is just right for gas diffusion while maintaining structural integrity. 9) Residual air - Always contain some air, ensuring continuous gas exchange even between breaths. This design makes the lungs incredibly efficient at meeting the body's high oxygen demands and CO₂ removal needs.

exercises.question: What would be the consequences of a deficiency of haemoglobin in our bodies?
exercises.answer: Hemoglobin deficiency (anemia) would have serious consequences: 1) Reduced oxygen transport - Less hemoglobin means less oxygen-carrying capacity, leading to insufficient oxygen delivery to tissues. 2) Fatigue and weakness - Cells don't receive adequate oxygen for energy production, causing constant tiredness and physical weakness. 3) Shortness of breath - Body tries to compensate by breathing faster and deeper to get more oxygen. 4) Pale appearance - Reduced red blood cells and hemoglobin cause pale skin, nails, and inner eyelids. 5) Rapid heartbeat - Heart works harder to pump blood and deliver available oxygen to tissues. 6) Dizziness and headaches - Brain receives insufficient oxygen, affecting cognitive function. 7) Cold hands and feet - Poor circulation due to reduced oxygen-carrying capacity. 8) Reduced physical performance - Unable to sustain physical activities due to inadequate oxygen supply to muscles. 9) Impaired immune function - Overall health deterioration affects body's ability to fight infections. 10) In severe cases - Can lead to organ damage due to chronic oxygen deprivation. This condition requires medical treatment to restore normal hemoglobin levels.

exercises.question: Describe double circulation of blood in human beings. Why is it necessary?
exercises.answer: Double circulation means blood passes through the heart twice during one complete cycle: Pathway: 1) Pulmonary circulation - Right ventricle → lungs (for oxygenation) → left atrium. 2) Systemic circulation - Left ventricle → body tissues (oxygen delivery) → right atrium. Complete cycle: Deoxygenated blood from body → right atrium → right ventricle → lungs → left atrium → left ventricle → body tissues → back to right atrium. Why it's necessary: 1) Complete separation - Prevents mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood, ensuring maximum oxygen efficiency. 2) High pressure maintenance - Left ventricle can pump oxygenated blood at high pressure to reach all body parts. 3) Efficient oxygenation - Blood gets fully oxygenated in lungs before being sent to body tissues. 4) Energy requirements - Humans are warm-blooded with high energy needs, requiring highly efficient oxygen delivery. 5) Pressure regulation - Different pressures for pulmonary and systemic circulation optimize both lung and tissue perfusion. This system is essential for maintaining the high metabolic rate required for constant body temperature and active lifestyle of mammals and birds.

exercises.question: What are the differences between the transport of materials in xylem and phloem?
exercises.answer: Transport differences between xylem and phloem: Xylem transport: 1) Materials - Water and dissolved minerals. 2) Direction - Unidirectional (upward from roots to leaves). 3) Energy requirement - No energy needed; uses physical forces (transpiration pull, root pressure). 4) Driving force - Transpiration pull (main), root pressure, cohesion-tension. 5) Speed - Relatively fast. 6) Tissue structure - Dead vessels and tracheids. 7) Process - Passive transport through physical forces. Phloem transport: 1) Materials - Organic food (sucrose), amino acids, hormones. 2) Direction - Bidirectional (up and down as per plant needs). 3) Energy requirement - Requires ATP energy for active transport. 4) Driving force - Pressure flow mechanism using osmotic pressure. 5) Speed - Slower than xylem. 6) Tissue structure - Living sieve tubes with companion cells. 7) Process - Active transport using metabolic energy. 8) Seasonal variation - Spring: stored food moves to growing buds; Growing season: food moves from leaves to storage organs. Both systems work independently but coordinately to meet plant's nutritional and structural requirements.

exercises.question: Compare the functioning of alveoli in the lungs and nephrons in the kidneys with respect to their structure and functioning.
exercises.answer: Comparison of alveoli and nephrons: Similarities: 1) Filtration units - Both are functional units of their respective organs. 2) Large numbers - Millions present in each organ for maximum efficiency. 3) Extensive surface area - Both designed to maximize surface area for their functions. 4) Thin walls - Both have very thin walls for easy exchange/filtration. 5) Rich blood supply - Surrounded by dense capillary networks. 6) Selective process - Both selectively handle materials (gases vs. substances). Differences: Alveoli: 1) Function - Gas exchange (O₂ in, CO₂ out). 2) Structure - Balloon-like air sacs. 3) Process - Simple diffusion of gases. 4) Materials - Only gases (oxygen and carbon dioxide). 5) Location - End of respiratory passages. 6) Wall structure - Single layer of epithelial cells. Nephrons: 1) Function - Blood filtration and urine formation. 2) Structure - Cup-shaped capsule with long tubule. 3) Process - Filtration followed by selective reabsorption. 4) Materials - Water, salts, glucose, amino acids, urea. 5) Location - Throughout kidney tissue. 6) Structure - Complex with multiple parts (capsule, tubule, collecting duct). Both are essential for homeostasis - alveoli for gas balance, nephrons for chemical and water balance.

summary.title: Life Processes
key_concepts: Nutrition - autotrophic and heterotrophic modes of obtaining and processing food
Respiration - aerobic and anaerobic breakdown of food for energy production
Transportation - movement of materials within organisms via circulatory and vascular systems
Excretion - removal of metabolic waste products from the body
summary.summary: This chapter explores the fundamental life processes that maintain living organisms. It begins by establishing that molecular movement is essential for life, as organisms must constantly repair and maintain their organized structures. The chapter covers four major life processes: nutrition (how organisms obtain food through autotrophic or heterotrophic means), respiration (how food is broken down to release energy through aerobic or anaerobic pathways), transportation (how materials are moved throughout the body via blood vessels in animals and xylem/phloem in plants), and excretion (how waste products are removed from the body). Each process is examined in detail, showing how single-celled organisms perform these functions simply through their cell surface, while complex multicellular organisms have developed specialized organs and systems. The chapter emphasizes how these processes work together continuously to sustain life, even when organisms appear inactive, and how they have evolved differently across various species based on their environmental needs and body designs.
